Award.AbstractNarration:
This award provides funding to help defray the expenses of participants in the conference "Southeast Analysis Meeting: SEAM 2013" that will be held March 15-16, 2013, on the campus of Virginia Tech.

This event is the latest in a twenty-eight-year-long series that has hosted conferences covering a wide spectrum of subareas of analysis and that has become the leading venue in the U.S. for function-theoretic operator theory. SEAM 2013 will again span a broad swath of analysis, featuring plenary speakers who will address the following topics: operator theory (Anna Skripka), mathematical physics (Fritz Gesztesy), harmonic analysis on fractals and associated wavelet and multiscale analysis (Palle Jorgensen), free noncommutative analysis (Dmitry Kaliuzhnyi-Verbovetskyi). The conference program provides ample opportunity for graduate students, postdocs, and other young scientists to present their work.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The 29th Southeastern Analysis Meeting (SEAM 2013) took place on the Virginia Tech campus in Blacksubrg, VA on Friday March 15 and Saturday March 16, 2013.  There were 5 plenary lectures:

Anna Skripka (University of New Mexico), "Taylor approximations of operator functions",

Dmitry Kaliuzhnyi-Verbovetskyi (Drexel University0, "Noncommutative function theory: a bird's-eye view,

Carl Cowen (Indiana University-Purdue University at Indianapolis),"Rota's universal operators and invariant subspaces in Hilbert spaces",

Palle Jorgensen (University of Iowa), "Multiresolutions, multivariable operator theory, and representations",

Fritz Gesztesy (University of Missouri-Columbia), Positivity preserving operators, heat kernel, and Green's function bounds for second order elliptic operators wiht Robin-type boundary conditions".

In addition there were 42 parallel-session talks convering traditional SEAM topics in Operator Theory and Complex Analysis as well as broadening talks dealing with applied topics in modern engineering and mathematical physics. In addition to the speakers there were some 40 additional participants giving a good mix of senior- and junior-leval participants contributing to the success of the meeting.

Perhaps the highlight of the meeting and certainly the most highly attended talk was the lecture of Carl Cowen who surveyed results from his recent work with Eva Gallardo-Gutierrez concerning the existence of a universal operator (in the sense that a a nonzero scalar multiple of any Hilbert-space operator is unitarily eqivalent to the restriction of the univeral operator to an invariant subspace) which commutes with a nonzero compact operator. Iin view of other known results in the area, this result is tantalizingly close to a positive resolution of a long outstanding problem in Operator Theory, namely, the Invariant Subspace Problem.
